bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 165, Number 110 (Friday, June 28, 2019)][House][Pages H5265-H5266]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. SCHAKOWSKY:H.R. 3605.[[Page H5266]]Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3The Congress shall have Power . . . To regulate Commercewith foreign Nations, and among the several States, and withthe Indian Tribes.

item.title: Protecting American Consumers from Robocalls Act

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Communications and Technology.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

summary.text:
Protecting American Consumers from Robocalls Act

This bill expands the private right of action that is available against telemarketers that call individuals who have registered their phone numbers on the National Do Not Call Registry. The bill permits bringing a lawsuit after receiving one such call, while current law requires at least two calls from the same telemarketer within a 12-month period before a lawsuit can be filed.

bill.title: Protecting American Consumers from Robocalls Act

item.title: Protecting American Consumers from Robocalls Act
To expand the private right of action under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act for calls in violation of the Do Not Call rules.
Protecting American Consumers from Robocalls Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Communications and Technology.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
